conclusion: To solve the problem, consider the forces acting on each body and the equilibrium conditions.
The image shows three hemispherical bodies A, B, and C with radii R placed on a rough horizontal ground. Bodies A and B are touching each other, and body C is placed between them.

The masses of A, B, and C are m, 2m, and m respectively. The coefficient of kinetic friction between A, B, and the ground is μ = √3/6. The maximum static friction equals sliding friction, and gravitational acceleration is g.
Body A is on the left, body B is on the right, and body C is on top, with their bases touching the ground.
The force of gravity mg acts downward on body A.
The force of gravity 2mg acts downward on body B.
The force of gravity mg acts downward on body C.
The ground exerts a normal force N upward on each body.
For body A to be in equilibrium, the sum of the forces acting on it must be zero.
For body B to be in equilibrium, the sum of the forces acting on it must be zero.
For body C to be in equilibrium, the sum of the forces acting on it must be zero.
The normal force N exerted by the ground on body A must be equal to the weight of body A, so N = mg.
The frictional force f is given by the coefficient of kinetic friction μ times the normal force N.
Substituting the values, f = μN = μmg.
Substituting μ = √3/6, the frictional force f = (√3/6)mg.
The magnitude of the normal force N exerted by the ground on body A is mg.
The magnitude of the frictional force f exerted by the ground on body A is (√3/6)mg.
